newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Southeast spot power firm amid nuke outages.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Southeast spot power firm amid nuke outages.

text.p: Spot wholesale electricity prices in the southeastern U.S. firmed Wednesday amid outages of several large nuclear generating station in the region, market sources said.
"It didn't see much (price) change," said a Midwest-based power marketer.
Late Tuesday, Duke Power Co's 846 megawatt (MW) Oconee 2 nuclear unit in Seneca, S.C., was taken out of service after a steampipe exploded, injuring seven workers.
The Oconee unit resumed operation briefly Tuesday after being shut last weekend to repair a leaking valve.
Duke said it has not scheduled a restart date when Oconee 2 would return to service following Tuesday's incident.
Two Florida nuclear units remained off line: Florida Power and Light Co's Turkey Point 3 nuclear unit in Florida City, Fla., and Florida Power Corp's 825 Crystal River 3 unit in Red Level, Fla.

In the Southeastern Reliability Council (SERC), non-firm power for heavy demand hours on Thursday for delivery into the northern portion of Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) system was quoted near $17.00 a megawatt hour (MWh), higher than Tuesday's quote of $16.25 for Wednesday.
Thursday's peak electricity in southern TVA was valued near $20.00, compared with Tuesday's $19.25-$20.00 range.
TVA was heard offering peak, non-firm power for Thursday at $18.00.
At the Georgia/Florida border, peak, non-firm power was quoted at $21.00-$21.50 a MWh for Thursday, compared with Tuesday's range of $20.00-$23.50.
